captions.text:
CHRIS HARRIS: In February, I
bought a rally car, a very
cheap Rally car.

The idea was to compete in a few
events this year with my

friend, Dan, another motoring
writer bloke.

We're both going to co-drive
for each other.

And this is the story of
our first test day.

I suppose this is also the story
of real-life motorsport,

how we went from this, via lots
of this, to get to this--

real motorsport,
real nonsense.
[ENGINE REVVING]

CHRIS HARRIS: The process
didn't start well.

I borrowed a trailer, hit a
rock, got a puncture, and
couldn't find a replacement.

When you say special order, I
mean, it's not a 335/20P0.

The next problem was my
knackered old Range Rover.

The cooling fan was chewing
30-amp fuses like wine gums.

So we needed to steal a few
from the rally car.

Well, we should have
a fan now--

3.9-liter V8 with about
8 horsepower.

OK, I'm not sure it will
start, though.
It didn't last night.
[IGNITION]
CHRIS HARRIS: There she goes.
Ha, ha.

And with that, we were ready for
the off, with hope in our
hearts and the promise of cheap
oversteer on the horizon.
Neil was shooting.
I was driving.

Dan was wearing completely
inappropriate clothing for a
gravel test.

And his friend, Adam, had
modeled his hair on a Noel
Edmonds' Swap Shop poster.

But the drive with the lads is
always the very best bit.

So we set the compass and
began with an earnest

discussion on the intricacies
of ZZ Top lyrics.

CHRIS HARRIS: You didn't have
to hold it, but you did.

MALE SPEAKER: But you
did, but you did.
CHRIS HARRIS: And I thank you.
MALE SPEAKER: What a band.

MALE SPEAKER: What will
I talk about?

CHRIS HARRIS: Those soaring
spirits dipped about 20

minutes later when we found out
that I hadn't punctured
one tire, I'd punctured two.

The Tire Weld was about to
spring into action when the

Range Rover immobilized
itself.

The newly functioning Kenlowe
fans drained the battery, and

we started begging strangers
for a jump start.

Sadly, the cables weren't
long enough to
reach a Sprinter van.

And this transit driver thought
I was about to rob him
and scalp it.

So it was left to a
kind couple in a
Picasso to save the day.
But now we had a dilemma--

leave the engine running and
risk a fuse blowing and an

overheat, or shut it off and
risk it not starting again.

But luckily, another blown tire
distracted us from the

agony of that particular
choice.

And by the time we'd reached
Phil Price's, we were looking
especially ragged.

With the Range Rover knackered,
the trailer

double-knackered, would the
BMW actually start?
[SPUTTERING ENGINE SOUNDS]
MALE SPEAKER: That's the one.

CHRIS HARRIS: We've still got
two service lights on there.
[SPUTTERING ENGINE SOUNDS]
[LAUGHING]
[IGNITION ENGAGES]
MALE SPEAKER: God, yes, yes!

CHRIS HARRIS: What
do you reckon?

MALE SPEAKER: This
is a business.
CHRIS HARRIS: There it is.

I thought it was about
150 horsepower.

But I'm led to believe
it's 170 horsepower.

No idea what the torque
figure is.
It's got some fluid in it now.

Come have a look
at the dipper.

So we finally made it to Phil
Price Rally School in the

middle of Wales, not far
from Radnor Forest.

And typically for Wales, it's
absolutely lashing with rain.

But I don't mind because
the Rally car's there.
You turn the key, it starts.

The power steering sounds like
there's a small mammal living
in it somewhere.
The Range Rover's half-dead.
The kit is ruined.

But then, it was shagged
before we started.

And that's the whole point of
this budget rallying exercise.

There's a crash helmet that
I last wore in 2005.

And it's been in the
shed ever since.
You caught that?

Do you reckon Sebastien
Loeb does this?

Mops the mold out of his
old crash helmet
before he puts it on?
Booties?
I dress in my booties?

MALE SPEAKER: This is a
[INAUDIBLE] car, yeah?
CHRIS HARRIS: Yeah.
Rally.

The 325 Rally car,
here we come.
Purchased for 4,000 pounds.

I know we it looks a bit
of a flea pit for that.

But that gives us a car ready
to go, ready to be used on

days like this, and in
the championship.
But do you know what?

We're having so much fun today,
that sometimes you

wonder whether actually you
do need to go and do a
championship.

Just come out in your 4,000 car,
spend a few hundred quid

renting Phil Price's
for the day.

Just come and go sideways
and feel the car move
around, have some fun.
[ENGINE REVVING]
CHRIS HARRIS: Ha, ha, ha.

Anyhow, I've got very
knackered old
tires on the back.

It's very slippery, and
it's just perfect.
It's where I want to be.
It's what I want to be doing.

This is the E30 BMW
325i Rally car.

Well, that's what the
bloke who sold it to
me called it anyway.

And there's no reason
to doubt his
description, I don't think.

It came with a few wheels,
tires, broken components, and

reputedly, a spare
2.7 Alpina block.

All that mattered to me was
it was rear-wheel drive.

There's a little series
for E30s in the UK.
It's run by Pat Flynn.

And one of the championship
rules is that extra points are

awarded for the most sideways
moment on a specific corner of
each event.

And this clearly makes it the
finest motorsport championship
event on the global calendar.

As for the spec-- well,
standard engine, spec

suspension in tires, standard
gear ratios, a locking diff,

the usual smattering of safety
gubbins, and away you go.

I love the fact that when I
bought it, the last owner

admitted it had led quite an
interesting life, and then

sent me photos of the one real
biggie it had suffered.

The old girl's been in a shed
for the last three months,

because we bought it and then
did nothing with it.
And now we got it out.

So 170 horsepower, what
does it weigh?
I have no idea.

It must be about 1,250, 1,300
kilograms, I suppose.
Tell you what.

On this kind of damp gravel,
it feels plenty
fast enough for me.

Unquestionably the best
4,000 pounds I've
ever spent in my life.
[LAUGHING]
It's mine as well!

There's a big gap between
second and third.

That's about the only sort of
serious technical issue.
It's big, and it's loose.

But it's rear-wheel drive,
so who cares?
[LAUGHING]

The temptation to see just how
much speed and angle you can

carry is always strong, and
it usually leads to the
inevitable.
So here's the inevitable.

See those crisscrossed
lines and that
large drop to the left?
Yeah.
My clenched buttocks did, too.

It won't surprise you to learn
that the post-test euphoria
was short-lived.

We loaded up, amazed that the
little 325 literally turned on

a key, took a day thrashing,
and didn't miss a beat.
Then we got another puncture.

This is what people call
grass roots motorsport.
People say it's great fun.

MALE SPEAKER: The last
road This one goes?
MALE SPEAKER: Yeah.

MALE SPEAKER: Let's just torch
the car then, yeah?

MALE SPEAKER: We'll just
leave the car.
MALE SPEAKER 2: Sorry?

MALE SPEAKER : We could've
just taken the
car and driven it.
Or is it not taxed?
CHRIS HARRIS: It's not taxed.

MALE SPEAKER: It doesn't
look like a Rally car,
though, does it?

MALE SPEAKER: I think we'd
probably get stopped if you

would have drove through
Monmouth like this.

CHRIS HARRIS: The irony of
today is that the silent

person behind me wearing the
Scandinavian headgear is
actually Adam Gould.
He's a proper Rally driver.

He's also best mates with
Dan, so he just came
along for the crack.

And all he's done today really
is change tires on hard

shoulders and ask truckers if we
can jump-start our car from
their battery.

Adam, what do you reckon to
what you've seen today?
[LAUGHTER]

ADAM: The whole thing's
been a shambles.
[LAUGHTER]

CHRIS HARRIS: To what
it's all about.
You get in a cheap, [BLEEP]

Range Rover, put a trailer
on the back, and
explode some tires.

And then take your
cheap [BLEEP]

racing car or Rally car
to Phil Price's.

And that's what it's
all about.

And if you offered me the chance
to go in a Cayenne

Turbo press car with a brand new
trailer, I'd do it every
single time.
I'm never doing this again.
It's been an absolute [BLEEP]

pain in the ass, if I'm
honest with you.
[LAUGHTER]

title: Cheap oversteer! The BMW 325i rally test day. A shambles. - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS

I'm going to look at an 85 318i Saturday, can someone give me some

comments.author: carl shneebly

comments.text:
Hey +flavourboss i'm building a drift car out of an e30 with a supercharged 
1uz. The original idea was just to put a 1uz in and hopefully some ITB's 
but it turns out that my dad (who is a mechanic that i don't live with) has 
an Eaton Supercharger laying around lol so that saves us time from 
turbocharging the 1uz. BMW e30's are really cheap here where I am (in South 
Africa) and im anyway planning on swapping in e36 suspension to handle the 
extra torque and a different ratio differential that will spin faster and 
hopefully not break. The engine is also going to be balanced and have the 
redline raised via software.

As for +justforever96 I respect that you prefer i6 engines for BMW's but 
saying that even the modern one should not have been a V8 (referring to the 
S65B40 found in the e92 M3) is quite a bold statement as many people prefer 
V8's because of the noise and N/A torque. Also im pretty sure that BMW knew 
what they were doing lol, especially the M-division. 

Going back to my build...
It is just meant to be a fun weekend drift/track car and i dont intend on 
it making 1000bhp etc. Anyway i hope that clears things up. 

Have a great day :D
comments.author: Luqmaan Joseph

comments.text:
+justforever96 You are absolutely right about the car being a fun first car 
even the base 318i is enjoyable.

But c'mon man, I do feel you about the I6 thing. But a 1UZ would be stella 
it only weighs in at 75kgs more and packing the punch of an additional 
100-120 or so horses.

What about a 2jz that fit your bill a little better?

(I am not trying to come across snide at all, and I respect your opinion. 
And of course I would never try to offend a BMW fan.) 

But, did you read my post where I gave a ton of good info on base engines 
to the guy and helped him to understand the differences between them, to 
make a more informed decision.

(He went for the 318i as that was what was available ho him and his wallet. 
Its a BMW, its a good choice, a bloody great choice haha.)

Someone simply chimed in and said he would love to have a 3 series himself 
and he happened to want a lexus 1uz and itbs to boot.

I said "Erotica <3" I think.

Either of us said too anyone that they needed a 275hp V8 swapped 3 series 
as a first car. Or that it would be a good idea, as it certainly wouldn't 
be for a learner new to the roads.

Oh and btw the getrag in the e36s was easy capable of wearing 300-350hp.
(Not that the guy said that he would be running the 1UZ on the stock 
drivetrain in his typed out dream car.
comments.author: flavourboss

comments.text:
Any E30 or E36 BMW is fine, especially if you're new to driving. Don't 
listen to the retards who think you have to have 300hp and 5 second 0-60 to 
have a good time in a car. A manual trans 4-banger 318 is still a fun, RWD 
car with great style and BMW sophistication. The chicks don't know the 
difference anyway. It's a hell of a lot more interesting and fun than your 
typical Nissan Altima or Chevy Malibu.
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text:
+Luqmaan Joseph You'd ruin a good BMW E30 by swapping in a V8? Fuck that. 
Inline is the only thing that belongs in a BMW (including the modern V8 
M3's). Also, if he can't even afford to get a decent 325i, then chances are 
he doesn't have the money to buy a decent 1UZ engine, pay for the 
fabrication is would take to swap it in and replace the entire drivetrain 
with something that could handle the power and torque....I guarantee a 318 
drivetrain isn't going to last....and also find an affordable set of ITB's 
that will just bolt up to a 1UZ and also fit under the hood of a E30 BMW. 
All these people with these bright ideas based on shit they saw in movies 
have no idea what it actually takes to do things like this....
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text: +Luqmaan Joseph Erotica <3
comments.author: flavourboss

comments.text:
318's are nice but if it was up too me and I didn't get a 325is then ill 
get the 318 and put a 1uz (V8 from a lexus or toyota) and put ITB's on 
there and a software tune to raise the redline - then i'll smile all the 
way to a head on collision #PaulWalker
comments.author: Luqmaan Joseph

comments.text:
+carl shneebly Awesome to hear mate, has to be the manual!!!

Have a talk to your local BM tech about the swaps, i'm unsure about the 
mounts and whatnot.

I wouldn't spend the money rebuilding the M10, (Not a bad engine, still fun 
as you say) but the cash would be better spent swapping in something better.

Google is your friend huh, and late nights.
The info's there and you have the car now, so your all set.

Just enjoy and take care of it, it'll reward you 10 fold.
Worry about more power later on, as you said its still pretty quick with a 
stick ;)
comments.author: flavourboss

comments.text:
+flavourboss Thanks. I ended up getting the 318i. I like it, its been fun 
to learn to drive manual on so far and learn to work on. The m10 is 
actually quicker than I thought it was going to be especially coupled with 
the 5 speed. But Im glad you taught me a little more about the engines. I 
was considering ( far down the road) doing an engine swap to a 6 cyl bmw 
engine, and was considering the m20, but the m42 sounds like a better 
option with the chain driven cam timing. I might just rebuild the engine in 
the mean time and add some stuff to give it more torque and hp.
comments.author: carl shneebly

comments.text:
The only 318 you want is the '318is' variant with the M42 engine opposed to 
the standard M10.

The M10 makes like 80hp stock and the M20 2.5 i6 goes as Harris says around 
170hp. 

The 318is M42 makes around 135hp and has DOHC and chain driven cam timing.
The M20 325i has belt driven cam and is a interference style engine where 
the valves step into the pistons reach, so timing belts and installation 
are a cost to consider. every 50,000kms they say.

Hope this helps.
comments.author: flavourboss

comments.author: Gladys Mason

comments.text:
Yeah, and they are impossible to find in good condition for cheap any more, 
because they've all been wrecked by people who rally them. Every year there 
are a few more, and there is no way you're finding a built-up rally Mk I or 
Mk II Escort for £4,000. You might find a normal, stock one for that much, 
but it'll take you another £4,000 to turn it into a rally car. And I'd 
rather see the few remaining cars taken car of and preserved, not taken out 
and wrecked by amateur weekend rally racers.
Anyway, an E30 is just as good a rally car as any RWD Escort.

comments.text:
+justforever96 No we use the term "Grand" here as well to describe £1000.  
 £4000 is actually more or less bang on $6000 at the current conversion 
rate, but either way, £4000 for a fully prepared, ready to go rally car 
with all the extras is about bang on the money I'd say.  So the people who 
comment saying it's not worth the cash he paid don't have a clue what they 
are talking about.
comments.author: Worzel Gummidge

comments.text:
+Worzel Gummidge Isn't "4 grand" usually only applied to US dollars? 4,000 
pounds is closer to $8,000, but either way, yes its worth it for what's 
been done to it. No way you could build that car for $8,000.
comments.author: justforever96

comments.text:
MSA approved Roll cage, MSA approved bucket seats, MSA approved harness', 
MSA approved fire extinguisher plus emergency activation cables, Footplate 
passenger side for navigators feet to rest on, hydraulic handbrake and 
adjustable brake bias, both of which he never mentioned, Emergency shut off 
controls all wired in correctly, plus the car must be fully road worthy 
with a valid MOT.  Plus he said he got parts with it and a spare lump. They 
are just a few things off the top of my head, so I'd say 4 grand is near 
enough bang on the money.  If you have ever tried to build your own rally 
car you would be suprised how much it costs to get a relatively "shit" 
looking car up to MSA standard.
comments.author: Worzel Gummidge

comments.text:
+MrTubs911 "Americans build better V-8's for towing then anyone else" uh 
no... if it's gassers, well, no, again the Tundras iForce V8 is litre for 
litre more powerful and has SO much more durability and power potential 
then any "merican" truck V8. So, no...
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
+MrTubs911 No, I'm saying the in the UK... where he is, the only possible 
'Merican" SUV he can get is either a Bummer 2 or a Tahoe, both of which, 
YES, the Toyota will out tow as it's diesel and also not a pile of broken 
rubbish like all GM products. I may have mixed up my words and not been 
clear.  Not to mention that "towing" to me doesn't only mean being able to 
maintain speed up hills but also that the truck in general isn't going to 
die on me way out somewhere meaning that again Toyota has the leg up. To 
me, being able to drag-race with a trailer on behind you, while COOL is not 
really useful esp when you're taking a fuel consumption hit just to have 
excess power in reserve.  To me Diesel's are all about having enough engine 
to pull/haul your load and a bit more for flexibility, but not a whole 
other engines worth just to compete with the guy in the OTHER truck next to 
you.  They make 4500's for a reason and I can see the point for true 
commercial users, but I'd wager 99% of the FS trucks sold in the US never 
actually get used as work trucks (even if they claim them as such on their 
tax returns).  I call it the "contractor syndrome" where they all "have to" 
buy a FS truck and then LIFT IT making it useless for work, but they're 
"fitting in" with the rest of the posers.  Kind of like GM SUV's and 
soccer-moms who COULD be helping the fellow motorists be more safe and 
driving smaller cars since they can't drive for shit anyway but no, they 
GOTTA have the biggest pile of shit the US has ever made by the thousands 
cause "every one of my girlfriends has one"  The US auto-industry reflects 
the sheer stupidity of the people of this country WAY too well.

Sadly we don't see the Toyota Diesels (not sure WHY???) here but as someone 
who's lived a fair few places around the world and run Toyota 4wd's 
professionally let me tell you if they ever bring a Diesel to the US it's 
game over for everyone but Dodge and the superior Cummins.   The newer gen 
70's have the 1VD-FTV single and twin turbo 4.5L V8 in them that is simply 
magical and having owned a low-pres Turbo'd 1HZ 75-series Troupy that 
consistently waded through windshield deep flood waters and then made 
2000mi treks across the Australian continent into all manner of wild places 
with only minimal, standard service being done to it.
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:
+Jeffrey Doud Yep brain fart... I just built a JDM spec. 1KZ-TE powered 
Hilux surf (LHD of course) here in the US and it's SO sad that we don't get 
the little oil-burners over here (or real Hiluxes any more) great truck and 
I fully intend to be buried in it hahaha.  My current 1st Gen Hilux Surf 
has over 330K miles on it and it's still my DD till I work out a few little 
bugs in the 1KZ swapped truck.
comments.author: Nor Wester (4Rescue)

comments.text:

owned a Corolla and a Rav4 all of them great vehicles tuff as nails.

only thing of the big 3 worth buying these days... And he couldn't get one 
in England.  They did sell the Hummer 2, but those are even bigger piles of 
shit then the Rover and GM crap SUV's they're based off.
